verses.text: These are the records of the generations of the sons of Noah: Shem, Ham, and Japheth. Sons were born to them after the flood.
verses.comment: Genesis 10 serves as a 'table of nations,' listing the descendants of Noah's sons who populated the earth. This sequence connects God's blessing of fruitfulness in Gen 9:1 with the faithful stewardship seen in history.

verses.text: The sons of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
verses.comment: Japheth is the ancestor of many northern peoples, later identified with Greeks, Scythians, and others. These lineages set the stage for prophecy, notably in Ezekiel's references.

verses.text: The sons of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
verses.comment: Ashkenaz came to be associated with peoples in modern Europe. Mention of Togarmah links to Ezekiel's prophecies concerning far distant lands.

verses.text: The sons of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Dodanim.
verses.comment: Javan is the ancestor of the Greeks, showing the spread of people into the Mediterranean. Tarshish and Kittim were names for distant lands, demonstrating the universal reach of Noah's lineage.

verses.text: From these, the coastland peoples separated into their lands, each with its own language, by their families, in their nations.
verses.comment: The division is both geographical and linguistic, anticipating the story of Babel (Gen 11). The division of nations hints at later fulfillment in the unity brought in Christ (Acts 17:26).

verses.text: The sons of Ham were Cush, Egypt, Put, and Canaan.
verses.comment: Ham's descendants settled the regions of Africa and the Levant. Canaan’s mention foreshadows later events in the biblical narrative, setting up Israel’s land.

verses.text: The sons of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. The sons of Raamah were Sheba and Dedan.
verses.comment: Sheba and Dedan are recurring in prophecies of trade and prosperity, especially in Ezekiel. This genealogy frames future interactions and conflicts.

verses.text: Cush fathered Nimrod. He was the first mighty man on earth.
verses.comment: Nimrod is remembered as a great leader and empire-builder, prefiguring later historical kingdoms. His prominence foreshadows themes of human ambition and its limitations.

verses.text: He was a mighty hunter before the LORD. Therefore it is said, 'Like Nimrod, a mighty hunter before the LORD.'
verses.comment: The phrase 'before the LORD' adds divine acknowledgment of his prowess. His status echoes both strength and submission to God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: The beginning of his kingdom was Babel, Erech, Akkad, and Calneh, in the land of Shinar.
verses.comment: Nimrod's founding of Babel and Shinar directly connects to the Babel story and early Mesopotamian civilization—a reminder of both glory and confusion arising from pride.

verses.text: From that land he went into Assyria and built Nineveh, Rehoboth-Ir, Calah,
verses.comment: Nineveh becomes significant in later prophecy (Jonah), symbolizing both the might of human empires and their need for repentance.

verses.text: and Resen between Nineveh and Calah; that is the great city.
verses.comment: Resen's mention as a 'great city' foreshadows the future importance of these regions and their moral significance in prophecy.

verses.text: Egypt fathered Ludim, Anamim, Lehabim, Naphtuhim,
verses.comment: These names identify various North African peoples, ancestors to significant nations often interacting with Israel.

verses.text: Pathrusim, Casluhim (from whom came the Philistines), and Caphtorim.
verses.comment: The origin of the Philistines is traced here, setting up future conflict with Israel. The reference to Caphtorim links them to Crete.

verses.text: Canaan fathered Sidon his firstborn, and Heth,
verses.comment: Sidon was a major Phoenician city. Heth is an ancestor to the Hittites, significant in later Biblical history and covenants.

verses.text: and the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
verses.comment: These tribes inhabited the land later promised to Abraham, highlighting the deep ancestral roots behind later events.

verses.text: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
verses.comment: Part of the list of people groups in Canaan, showing the complexity of the region’s population prior to the fulfillment of God’s promise.

verses.text: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites. Afterward, the families of the Canaanites spread abroad.
verses.comment: This dispersion anticipates the later conquest and division of Canaan, revealing the long-standing complexity of its people.

verses.text: The territory of the Canaanites was from Sidon, as far as Gerar, up to Gaza; and as far as Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, up to Lasha.
verses.comment: The land boundaries foreshadow future conflict and divine judgment, as seen later in the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah.

verses.text: These are the sons of Ham, by their families, by their languages, in their lands, in their nations.
verses.comment: The emphasis on families, languages, and lands echoes the later Tower of Babel narrative on the global diversity and unity under God.

verses.text: To Shem also, the father of all the children of Eber, and elder brother of Japheth, sons were born.
verses.comment: Shem’s lineage is of particular significance, as Eber is the ancestor of the Hebrews, leading eventually to Abraham and the messianic promises.

verses.text: The sons of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, and Aram.
verses.comment: This line traces the peoples of the Middle East, especially the ancestry of the Hebrews and civilizations such as Elam and Assyria.

verses.text: The sons of Aram were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
verses.comment: Uz is noted as the homeland of Job, connecting wisdom literature to these ancient roots.

verses.text: Arpachshad fathered Shelah, and Shelah fathered Eber.
verses.comment: Eber’s lineage is crucial, as it eventually leads to Abram, ancestor of God's chosen people. This genealogical accuracy reinforces the continuity of the promise.

verses.text: To Eber were born two sons: the name of the one was Peleg, for in his days the earth was divided; and his brother’s name was Joktan.
verses.comment: Peleg’s name means 'division,' possibly referring to the dispersion at Babel and the division of languages, pointing to a providential guidance in history.

verses.text: Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
verses.comment: These names mark the tribes settling in southern Arabia, evidence of the wide spread of Semitic peoples.

verses.text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
verses.comment: Further descendants of Joktan, each representing distinct clans and settlements.

verses.text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
verses.comment: Sheba is associated with the famous queen in Solomon’s time, linking genealogy to wisdom and wealth (1 Kings 10:1).

verses.text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were the sons of Joktan.
verses.comment: Ophir is key for its association with gold in Solomon’s time, suggesting historical prosperity among these lines.

verses.text: Their dwelling was from Mesha as you go toward Sephar, the hill country of the east.
verses.comment: Geographical precision points to God’s faithfulness in providing for diverse peoples, foreshadowing later gathering of all nations in Christ.

verses.text: These are the sons of Shem, by their families, by their languages, in their lands, according to their nations.
verses.comment: Once again, divine providence oversees the spread and organization of nations. The careful recording reiterates the spiritual unity intended for humanity under God's guidance.

verses.text: These are the families of the sons of Noah, according to their generations, in their nations. From these, the nations spread out on the earth after the flood.
verses.comment: This summary frames all humanity as sharing common descent and purpose, central to understanding how salvation history unites both physical and spiritual families. This hints at the later unification of nations within Christ's one apostolic body.
